perturbation.original_text:
1.12 "User" means any person or entity that accesses one or more pages on the
      Intuit Sites and is transported via the World Wide Web from the Intuit Site
      to the Client's Site.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.12 "User" means any person who might access one or more pages on the
      Intuit Sites, or other websites linked to the Intuit Site.

1.13 "User" also means any individual who has registered for services
      irrespective of whether they actively use the Intuit Sites.
perturbation.explanation: The definition of 'User' has been broadened to include individuals who may not actively access the Intuit Sites and also includes users of other websites linked to Intuit Sites, changing the original definition of a user who is directly transported to the Client's Site. It will create ambiguity on who counts as a user, especially regarding data privacy rights and the scope of allowed data usage, creating misaligned terminology.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) and other data privacy regulations that define user consent and data collection scope based on actual site usage.

perturbation.original_text:
10.2 Transaction Fees.  Separate and apart from the fees in Subsection 10.1
      above, at such time as Client has acquired [***] New Customers (the
                                                    ---
      "Minimum Customer Number") Client will pay Intuit [***] of the Net
                                                           ---
      Transaction Revenues it receives from each New Customer acquired by Client
      above the Minimum Customer Number ("Transaction Fee").  Within fifteen (15)
      days after the end of each month, Client will provide a monthly report (the
      "Transaction Fee Report") to Intuit. The Transaction Fee Report will report
      the Net Transaction Revenue and Transaction Fees for such month. All
      Transaction Fees due per the Transaction Fee Report will be paid with the
      submission of such Report.
perturbation.changed_text:
10.2 Transaction Fees.  Separate and apart from the fees in Subsection 10.1
      above, Client will pay Intuit a discretionary amount of the Net
      Transaction Revenues it receives from any customer ("Transaction Fee").
      The amount will be determined solely by Client.
      Within fifteen (15) days after the end of each month, Client will provide
      a monthly report (the "Transaction Fee Report") to Intuit. The Transaction
      Fee Report will report the Net Transaction Revenue and Transaction Fees for
      such month. All Transaction Fees due per the Transaction Fee Report will be
      paid with the submission of such Report. Intuit has no recourse if Transaction
      Fees are not provided.
perturbation.explanation: The 'Transaction Fee' calculation is altered to become discretionary, determined solely by the Client. This contradicts the original intention where the fee was tied to a specific number of 'New Customers' and a percentage of 'Net Transaction Revenues'. This creates a legal contradiction because the modified clause implies Intuit has no guaranteed revenue from transactions, making the obligation unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring clear and definite terms, especially regarding payment obligations.

perturbation.original_text:
18.2 Applicable Law and Jurisdiction.  This Agreement and the performance of
-------------------------------      the parties under this Agreement shall be governed by and construed in
      accordance with the laws of the State of California, U.S.A., except that
      body of law concerning conflicts of laws.  In any action relating to the
      parties, the parties consent to jurisdiction in a state or federal court in
      Santa Clara County, California.
perturbation.changed_text:
18.2 Applicable Law and Jurisdiction.  This Agreement and the performance of
-------------------------------      the parties under this Agreement shall be governed by and construed in
      accordance with principles of equity and fairness. The location where disputes are resolved may be any location of Intuit's choosing.
perturbation.explanation: The modification removes the specified jurisdiction (California law and Santa Clara County courts) and replaces it with vague principles of equity and fairness, and it allows Intuit to choose where disputes may be resolved. This creates legal uncertainty by eliminating a clear choice of law and venue, and may be seen as unenforceable if the location is unreasonable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal law regarding choice of law and forum selection clauses in contracts, requiring them to be reasonable and not against public policy.
